elements that may not exist natively in browsers or may not be understood by screen readers and other assistive technologies.' ARIA roles, which are covered in this article, are generally used to describe elements:' [2593] list '' [2594] listitem '' ListMarker '•' StaticText 'that may not exist within HTML,' [2595] listitem '' ListMarker '•' StaticText 'which may not have full cross-browser support,' [2596] listitem '' ListMarker '•' StaticText 'which may have implementation gaps in screen readers and other assistive technologies.' [2597] paragraph '' StaticText 'For instance, ARIA roles can be useful in situations where native HTML semantics are not understood in legacy user agents (e.g., browsers).' [2598] heading 'Usage' [2600] paragraph '' StaticText 'ARIA roles are added to elements using the' [2601] code '' StaticText 'role=""' StaticText 'attribute, where' [2602] code '' StaticText 'ROLE_TYPE' StaticText "represents the specific role being added. Once an ARIA role is set on an element, it should not be changed, regardless of the state of the element. In some cases, roles have to be paired with the appropriate ARIA state or property. However, this article's examples have reduced markup to limit the scope to just ARIA roles." [2616] link 'Window Roles', url='http://127.0.0.1:8023/a11yproject/a11yproject.com/-/blob/main/src/posts/an-indepth-guide-to-aria-roles.md#toc_Window-Roles' [2617] heading 'Abstract roles' [2619] paragraph '' StaticText 'Abstract roles are only intended for use by browsers to help organize and streamline a document. They should not be used by developers writing HTML markup. Doing so will not result in any meaningful information being conveyed to assistive technologies or to users.' [2620] heading 'Document Structure roles' [2622] paragraph '' StaticText 'Document roles are used to provide a structural description for a section of content. A majority of the available roles in this category resemble available semantic HTML tags and it is recommended to only use them when an appropriate native tag is not available. The roles in this category are also not typically interactive in nature. However, they may be used to contain other roles that are interactive. The following examples of' [2623] code '' StaticText 'toolbar' StaticText 'and' [2624] code '' StaticText 'tooltip' StaticText 'roles, serve as good examples of when to use Document Structure roles to provide information to assistive technologies when the equivalent native HTML tag is not available.' [2695] heading 'Landmark Roles' [2697] paragraph '' StaticText "Landmark roles identify content areas within a page. They serve as navigational landmarks for the types of content areas that users may be interested in. These content areas include the page's primary content, collections of navigation links, and search functions to name a few." [2698] paragraph '' StaticText 'Most Landmark roles are also implicitly exposed via specific Grouping and Sectioning HTML elements. [2805] heading 'Live Region Roles' [2807] paragraph '' StaticText 'Live Region roles are used to inform assistive technologies, such as screen readers, of dynamic changes to page content, so that they can be announced to users. The reason for this is that dynamic changes may be visually noticeable, but likely will be missed by users with low or no vision.' [2808] heading 'Alert role example' [2810] paragraph '' StaticText 'The most commonly used Live Region role is the' [2811] code '' StaticText 'alert' StaticText 'role.' [2831] heading 'Widget Roles' [2833] paragraph '' StaticText 'Widget roles are used to describe common interactive patterns or those that currently lack semantic equivalents in HTML. In most cases, these interactive patterns will be JavaScript-driven. Widget roles should not be confused with' [2834] code '' StaticText 'role="widget"' StaticText 'which is itself an' [2835] link 'abstract role', url='https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#isAbstract' StaticText '.' Tabs rely on three Widget roles, namely' [2839] code '' StaticText 'tab' StaticText ',' [2840] code '' StaticText 'tabpanel' StaticText ', and' [2841] code '' StaticText 'tablist' StaticText '.' step_data.thought:
I'm now looking at the file 'an-indepth-guide-to-aria-roles.md', which appears to be a comprehensive guide about ARIA roles. This is exactly what I need to find information about ARIA roles and their proper usage. The file is displayed in the main content area of the page, and I can see it contains detailed information about different types of ARIA roles.

The file is organized into several sections:
1. Introduction to ARIA roles
2. Usage of ARIA roles
3. Categories of ARIA roles:
   - Abstract Roles
   - Document Structure Roles
   - Landmark Roles
   - Live Region Roles
   - Widget Roles
   - Window Roles

Each section provides explanations and examples of how to use different types of ARIA roles correctly. This is a comprehensive resource that explains what ARIA roles are, when to use them, and provides specific examples for each category.

Since I've found exactly what I was looking for - a comprehensive guide about ARIA roles and their proper usage - I should now inform the user about what I've found.
step_data.action:
stop('I found a comprehensive guide about ARIA roles and their proper usage. The guide explains that ARIA roles are one half of the predefined categories of attributes used in the ARIA specification to describe elements that may not exist natively in browsers or may not be understood by screen readers and other assistive technologies. 

The guide divides ARIA roles into six categories:

1. Abstract Roles - Only intended for browsers, should not be used by developers
2. Document Structure Roles - Provide structural descriptions for content sections
3. Landmark Roles - Identify navigational areas within a page
4. Live Region Roles - Inform assistive technologies of dynamic changes to page content
5. Widget Roles - Describe common interactive patterns
6. Window Roles - Used when creating sub-windows to the primary application

Each section includes examples of proper implementation with code samples. The guide also emphasizes that ARIA roles should be used when native HTML semantics are not available or not supported across browsers and assistive technologies.')
